In Stanytsia Luhanska, where the Mission has monitored the process of disengagement of forces and hardware since June 26, a temporary bypass bridge for pedestrian traffic opened on 4 October. On the same day and onwards, the SMM saw workers from government-controlled areas starting to dismantle the broken section of the bridge. On 2 October, on the occasion of the International Non-Violence Day, the Mission observed a symbolic meeting near the bridge between four women activists from both sides of the contact line.

Between 30 September and 13 October, the SMM recorded about 17,000 ceasefire violations, including about 3,200 explosions. This compares with 9,650 ceasefire violations, including about 2,350 explosions, in the previous two-week period. The majority of ceasefire violations were recorded in the central part of Donetsk region.

The SMM recorded four civilian casualties, three of which occurred prior to the reporting period and one on 3 October due to shelling in Staromykhailivka. These reports bring the total number of civilian casualties to 122 (16 deaths and 106 injuries) since 1 January 2019.

The Mission observed fresh damage to civilian buildings due to gunfire and shelling in locations on both sides of the contact line.

The SMM observed 242 weapons in violation of withdrawal lines (170 in nongovernment-controlled areas and 72 in government-controlled areas) as well as mines and unexploded ordnance, including 22 antitank mines about 200m from civilian houses in Vodiane and 72 anti-tank mines within the area of the destroyed Donetsk International airport.

The Missionâ€™s freedom of movement was restricted 51 times, all but two in nongovernment-controlled areas. On 8 October and onwards, the SMM was able to access its camera site near the Petrivske disengagement area for the first time since 1 September 2019.

SMM unmanned aerial vehicles were targeted by small-arms fire on four occasions, and subjected to signal interference, assessed as jamming or probable jamming, on 51 occasions.

The SMM continued facilitating the repair and maintenance of essential civilian infrastructure, including to the power lines near Holmivskyi (which provide electricity to about 7,000 civilians), and an electric infrastructure in Pikuzy (which supplies about 100 residents of the village).

The SMM monitored gatherings related to recent political developments concerning certain areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions.
